Gallery Fun Facts Frequently Asked Questions Links and Contacts Map ListOfGallery Engineering Buildings //Strings for Links and Contacts Page Links and Contacts General Information Stacy Shane mgrss@appsci.queensu.ca Main Reception reception@appsci.queensu.ca First Year Engineers Aphra Rogers firstyr@appsci.queensu.ca //FAQ Strings Frequently Asked Questions Q) What are all these extra charges I see? A) University is expensive. However, some of the costs are actually optional. For example, student fees include a health and dental plan, bus passes, and gym membership. If you\'d like, you can opt out of those fees. Details here: "http://myams.org/society/about-your-ams/student-activity-fees" hi hi hi hi hi hi hi hi Map EngineeringBuildingsMenu NonEngineeringBuildingsMenu FoodBuildingsMenu HistoricalBuildingsMenu PictureViewCampusMap PictureViewCampusMap2 Dummy Button DUMMY\nCONTENT EllisHallBuilding Location: East side of University Avenue (58 University Avenue). Ellis Hall Main Uses Ellis Hall, constructed in 1958, is home to the Department of Civil Engineering, the Queen\’s Observatory, the GeoEngineering Centre, and the Groundwater and Flows Research Groups. The observatory houses a 16-inch state-of-the-art telescope used to study astrophysics. Ellis Hall is also home to multiple classrooms and an auditorium, where many first year engineering lectures are held. Interesting Facts Ellis Hall was one of the first engineering buildings at Queen\’s University to be built away from the north-east portion of campus. Ellis Hall also houses new and innovative classrooms, with interactive displays and unique seating arrangements, both of which allow for increased group work and participation. These classrooms are used for APSC 100 (Engineering Practice) Module 1, a first year engineering course based on group projects. ChernoffHallBuilding Chernoff Hall Location: South side of Bader Lane (90 Bader Lane). Main Uses Chernoff Hall, home to the Department of Chemistry is a new and innovative building composed of both classrooms, laboratory and administrative based sections, and an auditorium/lecture hall. Interesting Facts Chernoff Hall was built with a substantial contribution from Michael and Dorine Chernoff. Both him and his wife also created the, \‘Chernoff Family Award\’, which offers financial assistance to students around Canada who wish to attend Queen\’s University. ClarkHallBuilding Clark Hall Location: East side of Fifth Field Company Lane (30 Fifth Field Company Lane). Main Uses Clark Hall, home to the Campus Bookstore, the Golden Words newspaper head office, and the Clark Hall Pub, was built between 1949 and 1951 with finances paid entirely by engineering students. Clark Hall Pub is located in the top of the building, run by the Engineering Society, and serves as an inviting gathering spot for all students in applied science and other faculties. Interesting Facts Clark Hall Pub, first opened as a place for students and faculty to correlate recreationally. With the highly riveting, \‘Ritual\’ occurring every Friday afternoon, Clark Hall Pub\’s weekly events still serve as long standing traditions amongst members of the engineering faculty. DupuisHallBuilding Dupuis Hall Location: Attached to the north side of the ILC (19 Division Street). Main Uses Dupuis Hall is home to the department of Chemical Engineering, the Campus Computer Sales and Service Store, and the ITservices Main Office. Dupuis Hall contains two classrooms and one auditorium as well as multiple laboratory rooms focused on chemistry research. Interesting Facts Dupuis Hall was constructed in 1966 and is named after Nathan Fellowes Dupuis, a professor of math at Queens in the early 20th century, also a founder of the Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science. GoodwinHallBuilding Goodwin Hall Location: Attached to the east side of the ILC (25 Union Street). Main Uses Goodwin Hall is home to the department of Mining Engineering. It was built in 1972 and it was named after William Lawton Goodwin, the first director of the School of Mining and Agriculture, which is the modern day Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science. There are two major classrooms in Goodwin Hall. Interesting Facts : The department of Mining Engineering was the first active department in what evolved into the Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science. Goodwin Hall also houses the School of Computing. In June of 2002, a 20 kilowatt solar array was installed on Goodwin\’s roof. It was constructed as a learning, teaching, and research tool for Applied Science students. The array produces 18,000 kWh of electricity annually, which is distributed among Walter Light Hall, Goodwin Hall, and the Integrated Learning Centre. ILCBuilding Integrated Learning Centre Northeast corner of Union and Division Street (45 Union Street). Main Uses The Integrated Learning Centre (ILC) is home to the Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science. It is also called Beamish-Munro Hall. In addition, the building consists of group rooms, a multimedia facility, a site investigation facility, a design studio, and a prototyping studio and lab facilities. Beamish-Munro Hall was built to meet the needs of a growing multi-disciplinary Engineering faculty, as a model of sustainable construction. Interesting Facts Beamish-Munro Hall was named in honor of Robert Beamish (Sci\’60) and Donald Munro (Sci\’52). In 2005, a year after opening, it was selected as one of the most environmentally advanced buildings in Canada. [12] The ILC is a student-oriented building that was designed in collaboration with students. It serves as a resource to broaden awareness of green building design and environmental sustainability. The facility itself is instrumented as a working laboratory, where students can see structural elements of the building that are usually hidden and monitor systems like air quality, heating, lighting, and cooling using specially designed software, showing how sustainable practices can be incorporated into building design. Inside the front doors is a green wall that filters particles from the air before it is distributed throughout the building. Since 2004, it has won a numerous number of awards. InnovationCommonsBuilding Innovation Commons Main Uses The Queen\’s Innovation Commons is a new 70,000 square-foot complex that the University is planning to launch to condone graduate students innovative ideas and creations. This building will serve as a cohesive and collaborative learning environment that will help students succeed from an entrepreneurial standpoint. Special laboratories, offices, classrooms, machinery, and equipment will be made available to students to support their learning and expansion of their academic knowledge. The QIC is a new approach to teaching and designing, where students and faculty members have the opportunity to work out complex solutions to dignified problems. The Queen\s Innovation Commons will be equipped with world renowned design studios to support graduate students in their research. Students need to have opportunities and resources available to them to think critically and thrive in the workplace, and that is what is the aim of the QIC. The post secondary world is a competitive environment, but with the help of the Queen\’s Innovation Commons, graduate students will have the chance to have their ideas flourish and grow, with support from team members and colleagues. MclaughlinHallBuilding Mclaughlin Hall Location: South edge of University Avenue (130 Stuart Street). Main Uses McLaughlin Hall contains 3 classrooms and is home to lectures for Engineers. Additionally, many engineering design teams build their projects in McLaughlin Hall. It is home to the department of Mechanical Engineering. Interesting Facts McLaughlin Hall was completed in 1948. It was built on the site of the old Observatory. A story is told that Chancellor Dunning obtained the funds for Dunning hall by passing a note at a board meeting to Col. McLaughlin, which said “Queen\’s needs a new mechanical engineering building.” MillerHallBuilding Miller Hall Location: South edge of Division Street (36 Union Street). Main Uses Miller Hall, constructed in 1931, is home to the Department of Geological Sciences and Geological Engineering, as well as the Miller Museum of Geology. Miller Hall was greatly expanded in 1973, with the construction of the Bruce Wing. Interesting Facts Miller Hall hosts many rocks and minerals, as can be learned from APSC 151 (Earth Systems and Engineering), a first year engineering course discussing mainly geology. StirlingHallBuilding Stirling Hall Location: South side of Bader Lane (64 Bader Lane). Main Uses Stirling Hall is the distinctive round building, home to the Departments of Physics, Engineering Physics, and Astronomy. It contains many lecture halls as well as a range of smaller rooms used for labs and tutorials. Interesting Facts A notable feature of the building is a Foucault Pendulum, which hangs in the centre of the second floor. The pendulum swings in a pattern and at a speed determined by the rotation of the earth and the latitude of Kingston. WalterLightBuilding Walter Light Hall Location: North side of Union Street between Barrie and Division (19 Union Street). Main Uses Walter Light Hall is home to the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE). The fifth floor of the building includes an Information Processing and Communication Laboratory (IPCL). The research goals of the laboratory are to impact and influence the next generations of wireless communication systems and their application. It provides a unique research training experience for graduate students. In addition to the lab\’s own work, they also collaborate with other laboratories at Queen\’s, as well as, several other laboratories in Canada, such as the Communications Research Centre in Ottawa. Interesting Facts An interesting feature of the building is that every floor is connected to Goodwin Hall. BanBuilding Ban-Righ Cafeteria Location: South-west corner of University Avenue and Bader Lane (10 Bader Lane). Main Uses Ban Righ Dining Hall is the second largest dining hall on campus. Like Leonard Hall, Ban Righ offers a buffet-style service featuring nutritious entrees, desserts and more. Interesting Facts Vegetarian and special dietary options are available during every meal, and the Queen\’s Food site allows students to view weekly menus online. Ban Righ is not open on weekends. LazyBuilding The Lazy Scholar Location: Lower level of Victoria Hall (75 Bader Lane). Main Uses The Lazy Scholar is located in the basement of Victoria Hall, and serves as a retail food outlet and cafe for students, especially first years. Featuring flat screen TVs, pool tables, ping pong tables, a fireplace, and a comfortable lounge, the Lazy Scholar is the go to place for interaction amongst friends. Interesting Facts The Lazy Scholar often holds events such as open mic nights, accepts meal plans, and is open late during the week for those night time studying snacks! LeonardBuilding Leonard Hall Cafeteria Location: West end of Bader Lane (150 Queen\’s Crescent). Main Uses Leonard Dining Hall is a student cafeteria on campus. It provides new daily menu options, such as the vegan station, pizza bar, soup and salad bar and more. Interesting Facts Leonard Cafeteria is the largest dining hall on Queen\’s campus with over 650 seats. Special lunches and dinners are scheduled regularly at different times throughout the week. For those with a meal plan (mainly first years), this is a great place to grab food. Agnes Benidickson Field Location: South side of Fleming Hall, Kingston, Ontario. Main Uses Agnes Benidickson Field (AB Field) is a beautiful garden and recreational area to view and walk/sit in. Interesting Facts The field is named after Agnes McCausland Benidickson, the first woman Chancellor at Queen\'s University. AB Field is also the main location of Engineering Orientation Week activities and events. Grant Hall Location: East side of University Avenue (43 University Avenue). Main Uses Grant Hall seats 900 people and is used for meetings, lectures, concerts, ceremonies, dances, and exams. Interesting Facts Grant Hall is Queen\'s best-known landmark because of its tall limestone clock-tower. It is named after Queen\'s most important principal a national figure, George Monro Grant. In addition, Grant Hall was used as a military hospital during WWI and an entertainment centre and dining hall during WWII. Nicol Hall Location: South side of Union Street between University Avenue and Fifth Field Company Lane (60 Union Street). Main Uses Nicol Hall is home to many departments in the Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science. Interesting Facts Nicol Hall has historical significance since it was used as an army barracks in WWI. The building was named after former professor William Nicol, who also donated funds for building construction. Kingston Hall Location: Just south of Grant Hall (103 Stuart Street). Main Uses Kingston Hall was originally built to provide classroom and library space for the Faculty of Arts and Science. Currently, the hall is home to many of the Queen\'s language departments. Interesting Facts This building is named after the City of Kingston because they donated the funds for its construction. Along with Grant Hall, which is attached to Kingston Hall, the building served as a military hospital during WWI and as a training barracks for army courses in WWII. Summerhill Location: Just west of Arch Street (55 Stuart Street). Main Uses Since the 1860\'s, Summerhill has been the Principal\'s official residence, although only the east wing is now used for that purpose. Interesting Facts Summerhill is the oldest building at Queen\'s and originally housed the entire university. Prior to this, when Kingston was the capital of Canada in the early 1840s, the building was actually rented as a home to MPs. Over the course of its history, Summerhill has been used to house students, classrooms, the library, and even a gymnasium at one point. The east wing of the building was recently renamed Agnes Benidickson House in honour of the former Chancellor. Theological Hall Location: The south end of Fifth Field Company Lane (85 Stuart Street). Main Uses Theological Hall houses the School of Religion and the Department of Drama. It is the third oldest building on campus. Interesting Facts With money donated by Kingston citizens, Theological Hall was built as the university\'s main building throughout the late 19th century. Also around this time, the building became known as the "Old Arts Building" while Kingston Hall was the "New Arts Building." Theological Hall was actually fireproofed after a large fire took place in Kingston Hall in the early 1930s. Athletics and Recreation Centre Location: Just north of University Avenue and Union Street (284 Earl Street). Main Uses The Queen\’s Centre is a newly built common complex that serves as a community gathering place. It is home to the Athletics and Recreation Centre (ARC), the Drugs Mart Pharmacy, The Common Ground, The Grocery Checkout, retail food outlets, and rentable room spaces for clubs, rehearsal, and academics. The building incorporates academics and recreational activities, and calls all members of the community to its modern compound. Interesting Facts The ARC is a highly modern and developed recreation centre, being equipped with a 38 x 25 metre pool, gym, squash/racquetball courts, fitness rooms, aerobic/weight rooms, and designated class areas. Douglas Library Location: South-east corner of University Avenue and Union Street (93 University Avenue). Main Uses This library provides access to scientific and technical literature, journals, monographs, DVDs and more. Inside, there are study areas, seminar rooms, electronic classrooms and workstations available for users. Interesting Facts The current library was formed in 1997 when the old Douglas Library was renovated and the collections of 10 engineering and science libraries were compiled. This resulted in it\'s nickname, \'the engineering library\'. Gordon Hall Location: South side of Union Street, between University Avenue and Fifth Field Company Lane (74 Union Street). Main Uses Gordon Hall is home to the Office of the University Registrar, Career Services, the School of Graduate Studies, the Office of the Associate Vice-Principal and Dean of Student Affairs, Campus Tours, Records and Services, Student Awards, and Undergraduate Admission. Interesting Facts Gordon Hall was completed in 1911 as a gift from the government of Ontario. Initially the building was home to the department of Chemistry for over 90 years. Around 2002, the department of Chemistry moved to Chernoff Hall following the completion of its construction. John Deutsch University Centre Location: North-east corner of Union Street and University Avenue (87 Union Street). Main Uses The John Deutsch University Centre, constructed mostly in 1947, is home to the Alma Mater Society, the Tricolour Outlet, the Publishing and Copying Centre, Office of the University Rector, Society of Graduate and Professional Students, multiple restaurants, and much more. The Alma Mater Society is the student government at Queen\’s and its office is located in the centre. The Tricolour Outlet is the best place for finding Queen\’s attire, as well as purchasing a bus ticket to go home aboard the Tricolour Express. Interesting Facts The way nearly every Queen\’s student refers to the John Deutsch University Centre is “The JDUC” (pronounced jayduck). There is a Tim Horton\’s in the basement of the JDUC that always has a much smaller line than the one in the ARC (just north of the JDUC). Mackintosh-Corry Hall Location: Beside Tindall field and behind Ellis Hall (68 University Avenue). Main Uses Mackintosh-Corry Hall (abbreviated to Mac-Corry) is a very large and multi-purpose hall constructed in 1973. It is home to many departments belonging to the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, as well as the Mac-Corry Cafe. The Cafe features multiple food choices, including the Great Canadian Grilling Company, a favourite for burgers. Interesting Facts Mac-Corry is affectionately referred to as “The Maze” due to it\’s size and confusing layout. Due to its length, Mac-Corry is a great building to walk through to class during the winter. Nixon Field Location: East side of University Avenue between Union Sreet and Stuart Street. Main Uses Nixon Field serves as both the home turf of Queen\’s rugby and a general recreational field for students. Due to its close proximity to Kingston Hall, Nixon Field is also known as Kingston Field. Interesting Facts In April 2011, Kingston Field was rededicated as “Nixon Field” in recognition of a generous pledge from former Queen\’s students Gordon (BCom\’79) and Janet Nixon (BCom\’80). Nixon Field is located on the former militia parade grounds and ordnance lands of the British garrison. Stauffer Library Location: North-east corner of university and Union (101 Union Street). Main Uses Stauffer Library is the largest library on campus with study and research space for more than 1,200 students. It houses the university\’s humanities and social sciences collections. Stauffer Library is a 5 story building, and there are many other services available such as meeting rooms, maps, air photos, seminar and training rooms, and information services. Interesting Facts As such a huge building would require funding, the $48-million facility was a Queen\’s Challenge Campaign initiative that was funded by the government of Ontario and the private sector. The largest donation towards the library came from the Joseph S. Stauffer Foundation and therefore, the building was named in honor of Joseph S. Stauffer. In 1997, Stauffer Library was awarded the Governor General\’s Award for Architecture. Tindall Field Location: South side of Union Street, between University Avenue and Albert Street. Main Uses Located just northeast Victoria Hall and beside Mackintosh-Corry Hall, Tindall Field is a full-sized, multi-season playing field surrounded by a three-lane rubberized jogging track. Interesting Facts Tindall Field is named after Queen\’s legendary football coach, Frank Tindall. The field was originally located directly behind Victoria Hall, but was moved to its present location in 2008 because of a new underground parking garage and surface lot beside it. ARCBldg DouglasBldg GordonBldg JDUCBldg MacCorryBldg NixonFieldBldg StaufferBldg TindallBldg BenidicksonBldg GrantHallBldg NicolHallBldg KingstonHallBldg SummerhillBldg TheologicalHallBldg Jeffery Hall Location: West side of University Avenue (48 University Avenue). Main Uses Jeffery Hall is home to the Department of Mathematics and Statistics. Jeffery Hall is composed of six floors, three above and three below ground. Interesting Facts Jeffery Hall is named after Ralph L. Jeffery, the Head of Mathematics and Chair of Graduate Studies from 1943 to 1960. The reasoning behind having underground floors in Jeffery Hall was so that it would not detract from the tower of Grant Hall, across the street.
